content:
Hello, I am constructing some structures in ΘnSp\Theta_nSpΘn​Sp and I just want to make sure the following is cogent / ask where my intuition is flawed:

Consider a span of Θn\Theta_nΘn​-Spaces A←M→BA \leftarrow M \to BA←M→B, the ordinary pushout A+MBA+_MBA+M​B is a presheaf [Θnop,sSet][\Theta_n^{op},sSet][Θnop​,sSet] but it is not necessarily fibrant; it does not satisfy the segal conditions. I am looking to apply fibrant replacement to this pushout (A+MB)f(A+_MB)^f(A+M​B)f to obtain a Θn\Theta_nΘn​-space.

for example, gluing two representable 1-morphisms: Δ1+Δ0Δ1\Delta^1+_{\Delta^0}\Delta^1Δ1+Δ0​Δ1 is not a Θ1\Theta_1Θ1​-space, but the fibrant replacement should be like
(Δ1+Δ0Δ1)f≃Δ2(\Delta^1+_{\Delta^0}\Delta^1)^f \simeq \Delta^2(Δ1+Δ0​Δ1)f≃Δ2

Is fibrant replacement even valid for the segal conditions? Rezk's paper defines a cartesian model category whose fibrant objects are the Θn\Theta_nΘn​-spaces, so it should follow from general results on model categories, but the fibrations are built on top of a different model structure on [Θnop,sSet][\Theta_n^{op},sSet][Θnop​,sSet] namely, the injective model structure induced from kan fibrations in sSetsSetsSet. So I am a bit weary that fibrant replacement is acting with respect to the underlying model structure (i.e. adding identities) instead of with respect to the segal conditions (adding appropriate composites).

Thank you for your consideration of this question, below is a bit more info on what I am trying to do specifically.

A bit more info as to what I am trying to do:

Let Gk:ΘkSp\mathbb G_k:\Theta_kSpGk​:Θk​Sp the walking k-globe and ∂Gk:ΘkSp\partial \mathbb G_k:\Theta_kSp∂Gk​:Θk​Sp its boundary. We can define a "walking twisted cobordism" Tk:ΘkSpT_k:\Theta_kSpTk​:Θk​Sp meant to generalize the shape of the twisted arrow construction, but for iterated whiskerings of higher morphisms. Inductively TkT_kTk​ can be defined by

T1=G1+G1={0→1      2→3}T_1 = \mathbb G_1 + \mathbb G_1 = \left \{0 \to 1\;\;\; 2\to3\right\}T1​=G1​+G1​={0→12→3} and
Tk+1=(    [1](Tk)+∂Gk+1[3](G0,∂Gk,G0)    )fT_{k+1} = \left (\;\; [1](T_k) +_{\partial\mathbb G_{k+1}} [3](\mathbb G_0,\partial \mathbb G_k,\mathbb G_0)\;\;\right )^fTk+1​=([1](Tk​)+∂Gk+1​​[3](G0​,∂Gk​,G0​))f

I can give more info and pictures if desired, but I just wanted to give some context for the question above.

Yes the fibrant replacement will "add" the Segal and completeness conditions. As you said, this model structure is built as a (left Bousfield) localisation of the injective model structure [Θnop,sSet]inj [\Theta_n^{op}, sSet]_{inj} [Θnop​,sSet]inj​, and this localisation is done at the "walking Segal conditions" (see 5.1 of the paper you linked), the "walking completeness conditions". (see 7.6 of the paper you linked), (and also at the levelwise acyclic cofibrations of the previous level (n−1) (n - 1) (n−1))

To simplify, just consider the case n=1 n = 1 n=1, then the walking Segal conditions are inclusions the jn ⁣:Δ1+Δ0+⋯+Δ0+Δ1→Δnj_n \colon \Delta^1 +_{\Delta^0} + \cdots +_{\Delta^0} + \Delta^1 \to \Delta^njn​:Δ1+Δ0​+⋯+Δ0​+Δ1→Δn. The localisation of the model structure [Θ1op,sSet]inj [\Theta_1^{op}, sSet]_{inj}[Θ1op​,sSet]inj​ at the set of maps J={jn∣n≥1} J = \{ j_n \mid n \geq 1 \} J={jn​∣n≥1} is a new model structure on [Θ1op,sSet] [\Theta_1^{op}, sSet][Θ1op​,sSet] with the property that an object W W W is fibrant iff it was already fibrant in the injective model structure (i.e. W W W is pointwise a Kan complex), and furthermore, for all map jn∈J j_n \in J jn​∈J, the induced morphism of Kan complexes jn∗ ⁣:hom⁡(Δn,W)→hom⁡(Δ1+Δ0+⋯+Δ0Δ1,W) j_n^* \colon \hom(\Delta^n, W) \to \hom(\Delta^1 +_{\Delta^0} + \cdots +_{\Delta^0} \Delta^1, W) jn∗​:hom(Δn,W)→hom(Δ1+Δ0​+⋯+Δ0​Δ1,W) is a weak equivalence, i.e. Wn→W1×W0×⋯×W0W1 W_n \to W_1 \times_{W_0} \times \cdots \times_{W_0} W_1 Wn​→W1​×W0​​×⋯×W0​​W1​ is a weak equivalence, i.e. W W W is a Segal space. Proceed similarly for completeness.

Thank you, and I understand the localization w.r.t. the set of complete/segal maps which yields the model structure on [Θnop,sSet][\Theta_n^{op},sSet][Θnop​,sSet], defining ΘnSp\Theta_nSpΘn​Sp as the fibrant objects. 

I am interested in gluing together Θn\Theta_nΘn​ spaces via pushouts, and then "completing" them, to again be Θn\Theta_nΘn​-spaces, namely (A+CB)f:ΘnSp(A+_C B)^f:\Theta_nSp(A+C​B)f:Θn​Sp

In more detail, consider the suspension functor
[1]:ΘkSp→Θk+1Sp[1]:\mathbb \Theta_kSp \to \mathbb \Theta_{k+1}Sp[1]:Θk​Sp→Θk+1​Sp

Is it wise to construct a sequence of Θk\Theta_kΘk​-spaces by induction on k, using suspension, pushout, and fibrant replacement? I want to do something like 

Ak+1=(    [1]Ak      +Ck+1Bk+1      )fA_{k+1} = (\;\;[1]A_k\;\;\;+_{C_{k+1}} B_{k+1}\;\;\;)^fAk+1​=([1]Ak​+Ck+1​​Bk+1​)f
Where Ak:CatkA_k:\mathbb Cat_kAk​:Catk​ and Ak+1:Catk+1A_{k+1}:\mathbb Cat_{k+1}Ak+1​:Catk+1​

In my specific case, I am consructing
Tk+1=(      [1]Tk+∂Gk+1[3](G0,∂Gk,G0)    )f:Catk+1T_{k+1} = (\;\;\;[1]T_k + _{\partial \mathbb G_{k+1}} [3](\mathbb G_0, \partial \mathbb G_k, \mathbb G_0)\;\;)^f:\mathbb Cat_{k+1} Tk+1​=([1]Tk​+∂Gk+1​​[3](G0​,∂Gk​,G0​))f:Catk+1​.
Where Gk\mathbb G_kGk​ is the walking k globe [1]k(∙)[1]^k(\bullet)[1]k(∙) and ∂Gk\partial \mathbb G_k∂Gk​ is its boundary.
If I understand correclty, this is a picture of T2T _2T2​ and T3 T_3 T3​? pic

I'm not the one to say what is wise anb what is not, but I guess one problem with fibrant replacements in those kind of model structures is that it's very hard to say what they are exactly, so if you start to nest them by induction you will end up with very complicated objects.

If you insist that your Tk T_k Tk​ is a Θk \Theta_k Θk​ space, my first suggestion would be to instead define S1=G1+G1 S_1 = G_1 + G_1 S1​=G1​+G1​, and Sk+1=[1]Sk+∂Gk+1[3](G0,∂Gk,G0) S_{k + 1} = [1]S_k +_{\partial G_{k + 1}} [3](G_0, \partial G_k, G_0) Sk+1​=[1]Sk​+∂Gk+1​​[3](G0​,∂Gk​,G0​), and then only later Tk=Skf T_k = S_k^f Tk​=Skf​ to be the fibrant replacement of walking shapes you are interested in. So that you only have one fibrant replacement to compute, and do not nest them together.

Then, my second, more speculative, suggestion would be to not take a fibrant replacement at all: you say that you are defining "walking shapes" and, correct me if I'm wrong, but I imagine that you will use Tk T_k Tk​ to consider some collections of maps F:Tk→W F : T_k \to W F:Tk​→W, for W W W a Θk \Theta_k Θk​ space. This will define the generalised twisted arrows in W W W? If so, the general philosophy is that you do not need your Tk T_k Tk​'s to be fibrant in order to do that: cofibrant objects are good to model walking shapes, and fibrant objects are good to receive morphisms from those walking shapes.

For example, look at those walking Segal or completeness conditions whose shapes are not fibrant, and but are meant to be mapped into fibrant objects (to make them even more fibrant in some sense), or if you have a Θk \Theta_k Θk​ space W W W, then for any object K K K, the "functor category" [K,W] [K, W] [K,W] is again a Θk \Theta_k Θk​ space (regardless if K K K is fibrant or not), and [K,W] [K, W] [K,W] is to be thought as the Θk \Theta_k Θk​-spaces of K K K-shapes in W W W
Yes; the ability to use non-fibrant diagram shapes is one of the biggest advantages to using a model category to do higher category theory, there's no need to throw it away.

Clémence Chanavat your images:

differ from mine in the choice of
∂Gn+1=[1](∂Gn)→f[3](G0,∂Gn,G0)\partial \mathbb G_{n+1} = [1](\partial \mathbb G_{n}) \overset{f}\to [3](\mathbb G_0, \partial \mathbb G_{n}, \mathbb G_0)∂Gn+1​=[1](∂Gn​)→f[3](G0​,∂Gn​,G0​).
You are using the "middle inclusion" f=[f1,2](id)f = [f_{1,2}](id)f=[f1,2​](id),
I am using the "whiskered inclusion" f=[f0,3](!,id,!)f = [f_{0,3}](!,id,!)f=[f0,3​](!,id,!)
where [1]→fi,j[3]:Δ[1] \overset{f_{i,j}}\to [3]:\Delta[1]→fi,j​[3]:Δ are the respective face maps.

Here is how you do this gluing, note my usage of independent labels 1,2,1',2',1'',2'' to indicate gluing:
T

Re-arranged, these cobordisms look like classical cobordisms between boundaries of globes:
cob.

I would like to glue composible s-length chains together to get something like
Tn,s=Tn+∂Gn...+TnT_{n,s} = T_n+_{\partial \mathbb G_n}...+T_nTn,s​=Tn​+∂Gn​​...+Tn​, and Tn,0=∂GnT_{n,0} = \partial \mathbb G_nTn,0​=∂Gn​

Further, I would like to define a simplicial object
K∂Gn:Δop→sSetK_{\partial \mathbb G_n}:\Delta^{op} \to sSetK∂Gn​​:Δop→sSet
by K∂Gn([s])=Map(Tn,s,K)K_{\partial \mathbb G_n}([s]) = Map(T_{n,s},K)K∂Gn​​([s])=Map(Tn,s​,K)
and I want K∂GnK_{\partial \mathbb G_n}K∂Gn​​ to be a Θ1\Theta_1Θ1​-space.

I am wondering, to both Clémence and James Deikun's point, if regardless of the fibrancy of the Tn,sT_{n,s}Tn,s​ and due to the fibrancy of KKK, whether K∂GnK_{\partial \mathbb G_n}K∂Gn​​ is automatically fibrant (i.e. is a Θ1\Theta_1Θ1​-space). I need K∂GnK_{\partial \mathbb G_n}K∂Gn​​ to behave like a category because it will induce composable fibered actions on Map(Gn,K)Map(\mathbb G_n, K)Map(Gn​,K)

Thank you for your interest and consideration!

Btw the difference between the fibrancy points that both of you brought up, that [T,K] is automatically fibrant, and the property that I am looking for is that [Tn,K][T_n,K][Tn​,K] is not the exact structure I am looking to work with, it has the wrong objects and morphisms. I am constructing K∂GnK_{\partial \mathbb G_n}K∂Gn​​ by hand.

Perhaps there is a general notion that, given a cosimplicial object Δ→TΘnSp\Delta\overset{T}\to\Theta_nSpΔ→TΘn​Sp, the resulting simplicial object Map(T(−),K):Δop→sSetMap(T(-), K):\Delta^{op} \to sSetMap(T(−),K):Δop→sSet is a Θ1\Theta_1Θ1​-space?

This conjecture could take on the assumption that T:Δ→ΘnSpT:\Delta \to \Theta_nSpT:Δ→Θn​Sp is inductively built from colimits of suspensions of representables. Or, even more, if T is built from fibrant replacements of colimits of suspensions of representables
Ok I see better what you want to do (I was confused as to why you would called it generalised twited arrow, that makes more sense to me now hehe)

Concerning your definition of K∂Gn K_{\partial G_n } K∂Gn​​, I do not know how to make a simplicial object at all, since I do not see any way to construct the inner faces di ⁣:Tn,s+1→Tn,s d_i \colon T_{n, s + 1} \to T_{n, s} di​:Tn,s+1​→Tn,s​ for 0<i<s+1 0 < i < s + 1 0<i<s+1. Like you would want them to be a composite of the i i i th and (i+1) (i + 1) (i+1) th copy of the "tube" Tn T_n Tn​, but those composite do not exist in Tn,s+1 T_{n, s + 1} Tn,s+1​, so I guess let's take a fibrant replacement: but even then, if you somehow manage to explicit all your simplicial structure for s↦Tn,s s \mapsto T_{n, s} s↦Tn,s​ the best you can hope for is that your simplicial identities hold only up to some homotopy.

Maybe a not too bad alternative would be to construct your shapes Tn,s T_{n, s} Tn,s​ in strict ω \omega ω-category: since everything will be a polygraph it should not be too hard there to manage the composites and exhibit the simplicial structure for s↦Tn,s s \mapsto T_{n, s} s↦Tn,s​, (or even better, you can do this very easily with maps and comaps of regular directed complexes, but I don't want to do no proselytism) and then you use a nerve to send your construction to Θn \Theta_n Θn​-spaces (I assume there is such nerve, but wouldn't know where to find it in the literature), so you will end up indeed with a cosimplicial object Tn ⁣:Δ→ΘnSp T_n \colon \Delta \to \Theta_n Sp Tn​:Δ→Θn​Sp

As for your last question, I don't think this is the case in general, but yeah it feels it should be true in your case: like the inclusion i ⁣:Tn,1+Tn,0Tn,1→Tn,2 i \colon T_{n ,1} +_{T_{n, 0}} T_{n, 1} \to T_{n, 2} i:Tn,1​+Tn,0​​Tn,1​→Tn,2​ wants to be a weak equivalence, in fact even a fibrant replacement! But this inclusion i i i is nothing else than T(Λ21→Δ2) T(\Lambda^1_2 \to \Delta_2) T(Λ21​→Δ2​), thus by adjunction Map(T−,K) Map(T-, K) Map(T−,K) has the right lifting property against Λ21→Δ2 \Lambda^1_2 \to \Delta_2Λ21​→Δ2​, and similarly for all other inner horns: saying this should not be too far from saying that Map(T−,K)Map(T-, K)Map(T−,K) is a Θ1 \Theta_1Θ1​ space

Actually, I find your last question very instructive, at least for me: simplify it to the maximum so consider your basic twisted arrow shape to be only the arrow Δ1 \Delta_1 Δ1​, and works with quasicategories ≅Θ1 \cong \Theta_1≅Θ1​ spaces.

Now the question becomes: is there a functor S ⁣:Δ→sSet S \colon \Delta \to sSet S:Δ→sSet such that for all n≥1 n \geq 1 n≥1,

  • Sn S_n Sn​ is a quasicategory, and is somewhat a fibrant replacement of Δ1+Δ0⋯+Δ0Δ1 \Delta_1 +_{\Delta_0} \cdots +_{\Delta_0} \Delta_1 Δ1​+Δ0​​⋯+Δ0​​Δ1​.
  • The simplicial set sSet(S−,K) sSet(S-, K) sSet(S−,K) is a quasicategory, for all quasicategory K K K ?

well yes there is such thing, it's none other than the Yoneda embedding! Indeed, for all n n n, and Sn=Δn S_n = \Delta_n Sn​=Δn​ is a quasicategory, since it is the nerve of the category [n]={0→1→⋯→n} [n] = \{ 0 \to 1 \to \cdots \to n\} [n]={0→1→⋯→n}, and the inclusion Δ1+Δ0⋯+Δ0Δ1→Δn \Delta_1 +_{\Delta_0} \cdots +_{\Delta_0} \Delta_1 \to \Delta_nΔ1​+Δ0​​⋯+Δ0​​Δ1​→Δn​, also known as the spine, is an acyclic cofibration for quasicategories! And sSet(S−,K) sSet(S-, K) sSet(S−,K) is a quasicategory, since it is isomorphic to K K K by the Yoneda Lemma

Now, the same idea will also work to define your first twisted arrow shape T1 T_1 T1​, since T1,n=Sn+Sn T_{1, n} = S_n + S_n T1,n​=Sn​+Sn​ is also the nerve of the coproduct [n]+[n] [n] + [n] [n]+[n], and then maybe it reinforces the idea of building your cosimplicial object Tn T_n Tn​ first in polygraphs then passing to the nerve to get a Θn \Theta_n Θn​ space, since this is what this does for the base case T1 T_1 T1​ anyway

It would be nice if the Tn,−:Δ→ΘnSpT_{n,-}:\Delta \to \Theta_nSpTn,−​:Δ→Θn​Sp is actually a theta space. But to the above points, I am using them as probes so for now we seek Tn,−:Δ→[Θnop,sSet]T_{n,-}:\Delta \to [\Theta_n^{op},sSet]Tn,−​:Δ→[Θnop​,sSet] and leave fibrant replacement out of the picture.

Let A:ΘnA:\Theta_nA:Θn​, we have the map [3]([0],A,[0])→[1](A)[3]([0],A,[0]) \to [1](A)[3]([0],A,[0])→[1](A) to be viewed as collapsing the left and right 1-morphisms represented by the [0][0][0] into identities.

In particular we have maps:
[3](G0,∂Gn,G0)→dn+1[1](∂Gn)≅∂Gn+1[3](\mathbb G_0,\partial \mathbb G_n, \mathbb G_0) \overset{d_{n+1}}\to [1](\partial \mathbb G_n) \cong \partial \mathbb G_{n+1} [3](G0​,∂Gn​,G0​)→dn+1​[1](∂Gn​)≅∂Gn+1​

we also have
T1=yG1+yG1→δ1yG0+yG0≅y∂G1T_{1} = y\mathbb G_1+y\mathbb G_1 \overset{\delta_1}\to y\mathbb G_0 + y\mathbb G_0 \cong y\partial \mathbb G_1T1​=yG1​+yG1​→δ1​yG0​+yG0​≅y∂G1​

Assume for induction Tn→δn∂GnT_n \overset{\delta_n} \to \partial \mathbb G_nTn​→δn​∂Gn​ and build
δn+1=[1]δn+∂Gn+1ydn+1\delta_{n+1} = [1]\delta_n +_{\partial \mathbb G_{n+1}} yd_{n+1}δn+1​=[1]δn​+∂Gn+1​​ydn+1​.

There are a few details missing here because I haven't posted the full details of the TnT_nTn​ construction (I can but I would like to keep things intuitive). Essentially the δn\delta_nδn​ contracts all whiskering higher morphisms to identities, so [1](δn)[1](\delta_n)[1](δn​) contracts all whiskering k≥2k\geq 2k≥2 morphisms, and dn+1d_{n+1}dn+1​ handles the 1-morphisms.

Anyway, we are left with a reflexive graph
Δ∣1→[Θnop,sSet]\Delta|^1 \to [\Theta_n^{op}, sSet]Δ∣1→[Θnop​,sSet]
Tn⇉∂GnT_n \rightrightarrows \partial \mathbb G_nTn​⇉∂Gn​ and Tn←δn∂GnT_n \overset{\delta_n}\leftarrow \partial \mathbb G_nTn​←δn​∂Gn​
so we can generate the face and degeneracy maps of Tn,sT_{n,s}Tn,s​ by pushout

Clémence Chanavat this and essentially everything you said below that is what I am trying to do. I think at this point, the easiest thing to do is forget the fibrancy requirements on TTT and rearrange the pushouts in the definition of TnT_nTn​ to be amenable to the segal condition on [Tn,s,K][T_{n,s}, K][Tn,s​,K].

Thank you for the help!
